sentences.text: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures .
The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words .
Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented .
Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words .
Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics .
Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs .
The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

The analysis is grounded in a full scale two-level morphological description of Turkish word structures, which is described in detail within the paper. This description is based on a root word lexicon that contains approximately 23,000 root words, serving as the foundational element for the morphological analysis. The stem, which has a broader term of word structures, is crucial in this context, as it represents the base form of words to which morphemes can be added. The paper also addresses special cases that are exceptions to the established morphological rules, ensuring a thorough understanding of the complexities involved in Turkish morphology.

In the study of Turkish morphology, derivational and inflectional suffixes are recognized as a subset of morphemes, which are the smallest units of meaning in the language. These morphemes can be added to root words, with inflectional suffixes specifically attached to them to express grammatical features. Morphological rules, which govern the structure and formation of words, fall under the broader category of morphological description, alongside morphotactics and the two-level morphological description. The finite-state model is also a part of this morphological description framework. In Turkish, morphotactics plays a crucial role, and morphemes can create adverbial constructs that modify verbs and adjectives. Phonetic rules, including vowel harmony, are essential in understanding the pronunciation of these morphemes, as vowel harmony exemplifies how sounds within a word can harmonize. The PC-KIMMO environment is a computational tool that implements these morphological analyses.
